content: The "Clean Up Government Act of 2011" amends various sections of title 18, United States Code, including expanding the application of mail and wire fraud statutes, changing venue for federal offenses, increasing penalties for theft or bribery concerning programs receiving federal financial assistance, and enhancing penalties for violations of section 641. SEC. 5. Penalty for section 641 violations increased from ten to 20 years. SEC. 6. Penalties for bribery and graft increased to 20 years and 5 years respectively. SEC. 7. District of Columbia added to theft of public money offense. SEC. 8. Clarification of illegal gratuities crime. SEC. 9 clarifies the definition of "official act" under title 18, United States Code, to include acts within official duty, decisions, recommendations, or actions on any pending matter, and decisions that a government should not take action. SEC. 10 amends sentencing guidelines for certain crimes. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and amend its guidelines for certain offenses under title 18, United States Code to increase penalties. This is to reflect Congress's intent for more severe penalties due to the serious nature and growing incidence of these offenses, aiming for an effective deterrent. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and amend its guidelines for certain offenses under title 18, United States Code to increase penalties. This is to reflect Congress's intent for more severe penalties due to the serious nature and growing incidence of these offenses, aiming for an effective deterrent. The guidelines should appropriately account for factors such as harm to the public, level of sophistication in the offense, intent to cause harm, abuse of trust, and impact on public confidence. The guidelines should also consider whether the violation was intended to create a threat to public health or safety, injury, or death, assure consistency with other directives, and make necessary changes to meet the purposes of sentencing. SEC. 11. EXTENSION OF STATUTE OF LIMITATIONS FOR SERIOUS PUBLIC CORRUPTION OFFENSES. Chapter 213 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new section on corruption offenses. Prosecution for certain offenses, including bribery and extortion, must occur within 10 years of the offense. The new section in Chapter 213 of title 18, United States Code, addresses corruption offenses involving bribery chargeable under State law, violations of specific sections, and extortion under color of official right. The table of sections is amended to reflect this addition. SEC. 12. INCREASE OF MAXIMUM PENALTIES FOR CERTAIN PUBLIC CORRUPTION RELATED OFFENSES. The amendments made by this section shall not apply to any offense committed before the date of enactment of this Act. The text chunk amends various sections of title 18, United States Code, increasing penalties for certain public corruption-related offenses from "3 years" to "10 years". The amendment increases the penalty for coercion of political activity by federal employees from "three years" to "10 years" under section 610 of title 18, United States Code. SEC. 13. ADDITIONAL RICO PREDICATES. Section 1961(1) of title 18, United States Code is amended to include new sections related to embezzlement, theft, and fraud. Section 1956(c)(7)(D) is also amended to remove reference to public money, property, or records. Section 1956(c)(7)(D) is also amended to remove reference to public money, property, or records. Additionally, references to specific sections related to theft or bribery concerning programs receiving Federal funds are struck. SEC. 14 amends Section 2516(1)(c) of title 18, adding wiretap predicates related to embezzlement, theft of public money, bribery, and major fraud against the United States. SEC. 15 expands venue for perjury and obstruction of justice proceedings. SEC. 15 expands venue for perjury and obstruction of justice proceedings under specific sections of the United States Code. SEC. 15 expands venue for perjury and obstruction of justice proceedings under specific sections of the United States Code by amending the table of sections in title 18. SEC. 16 prohibits undisclosed self-dealing by public officials. Chapter 63 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include section 1346A, which addresses undisclosed self-dealing by public officials. This includes acts within their official duty and any decisions or actions related to their role. The term 'public official' refers to individuals acting on behalf of the government at any level, including officers, employees, or representatives. The definition of 'State' encompasses various governmental entities within the United States. The term 'undisclosed self-dealing' refers to a public official performing an official act to benefit their own financial interest or that of their spouse, minor child, business partners, or organizations they are associated with. The curr_chunk discusses the consequences for a public official who knowingly falsifies or fails to disclose material information regarding their financial interests as required by law. The curr_chunk introduces a new item in the table of sections for chapter 63 of title 18, United States Code, related to public officials. SEC. 17 amends Section 360(a) of title 28, US Code to allow disclosure of information in complaints against judges to the Attorney General or law enforcement agencies. SEC. 18 clarifies exemptions in certain bribery offenses. SEC. 18 clarifies exemptions in certain bribery offenses under Section 666(c) of title 18, US Code. SEC. 19 expands certifications regarding appeals by the United States under Section 3731 of title 18, US Code.
